Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research:Integration of Decadal Climate Predictions, Ecological and Human Decision-Making Models to Support Climate-Resilient Agriculture in the Argentine Pampas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The multi-faceted aspects of climate variability and climate change affect a variety of societal sectors, regions and issues, including sustainable development, poverty mitigation and food security. Decision makers at many levels-households, communities, regions and countries-will increasingly need credible information that combines state-of-the-art climate science with an integrative understanding of the dynamics of affected natural/human systems. The overarching goal of this project is to enhance society's capacity to act on regional information, e.g. decadal predictions. In particular, the project seeks to facilitate adaptation to a shifting climate and inform resilient decision-making in agricultural production - a human activity that is critically vulnerable to climate. The geographic focus is the Pampas of central eastern Argentina, one of the main cereal and oilseed producing regions in the world.

Well-informed adaptation to climate variability and change requires the capacity to 'translate' knowledge of decadal climate predictions into decision-relevant, sector-specific information and knowledge that is consistent with existing needs, procedures and decision protocols. To enhance the match between capabilities and expectations of decadal climate predictions, a sustained, iterative dialogue is implemented between climate scientists and multiple agricultural stakeholders. The goals of this dialogue are twofold: (i) to understand decision makers' information needs, beliefs, values and priorities, as well as the constraints under which they operate, and (ii) to provide useful feedback to the climate modeling community that will guide future model development and communication. As part of the project modern, rigorous statistical approaches will be applied to investigation of extreme climate events responsible for most societal impacts.

This activity has significant broader impacts: understanding the link between climate variability and decision-making is a fundamental issue that affects resource management in regions and sectors throughout the world. The project will provide an integrated analysis of responses to decadal climate predictions in agriculture - a prevalent, real-world natural/human system that plays a central role in global food production, food security and energy production. Project outcomes include guidance and best practices for decision-makers seeking to adapt to climate variability. The collaboration with scientists in Argentina will strengthen the ability of U.S. institutions and investigators to engage in integrative climate and natural/human systems science with a global scope and perspective. The active involvement of climate information producers and decision-makers will enhance considerably the likelihood of research outputs being incorporated into operational practice

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to inform adaptation to climate variability and change through development of an enhanced capacity to “translate” climate predictions and projections into decision-relevant, sector-specific information and knowledge that is consistent with existing needs, procedures and decision protocols. To achieve this translation, plausible climate scenarios were linked with physical, ecological and social models (e.g., modern downscaling approaches, crop simulation models, realistic models of human decision-making under risk and uncertainty). Specifically, we implemented an agent-based model (ABM) of agricultural production in the Argentine Pampas that successfully replicated historical patterns in land use, land tenure and agricultural system structure (numbers of farms/farmers, farm size distribution, etc.).

We designed an ABM validation framework that placed considerable emphasis on validation of model processes and components during model development. The design process involved extensive dialog with agricultural experts and literature review. This careful process ensured a realistic model design and representative behavioral rules: even initial simulations successfully reproduced the main patterns observed in the Pampas. Subsequent comparison between simulated and observed data helped refine model parameters and assess validity of results. Even though ABMs are increasingly used to simulate complex systems, most models are developed by scientists with little experience in software engineering concepts. As models grow increasingly complex, however, it is important to pay attention to software design so that models can be scaled up, alternative mechanisms can be swapped in and out, and individual components are as computationally efficient as possible. We shared insights from our experience in the development of a land use ABM to help researchers without computer science training to develop a good workflow for initializing models, running simulations and performing initial analyses.

An important component of the project focused on climate prediction and predictability across time scales (from seasons to decades). Research has shown that there is significant diversity in the location of the maximum sea surface temperature anomaly (SSTA) associated with the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO). The project explored differing extratropical responses, particularly over North America, associated with Niño events with the highest SSTAs in the Eastern Pacific and in the central Pacific, respectively.

Another goal of this project was to assess potential limitations or barriers for the development, implementation, and sustained provision of climate information. One of the outcomes of a dialog between producers and users of climate information was the strong interest on ensuring future availability of information and knowledge about the likely outcomes of potential adaptation actions. This suggested the need to advance in the exploration of issues related to the operational implementation of national and regional services. To this effect, we partnered with the Regional Climate Center for southern South America (RCC-SSA, www.crc-sas.org) – a component of the World Meteorological Organization’s Global Framework for Climate Services (GFCS) – is jointly led by Brazil and Argentina, and includes Paraguay, Uruguay, Bolivia and Chile as members.

The sustainable provision of operational climate services must be supported by an active, user-centric research program. Because climate services depend critically on diagnostics of recent conditions and predictions/projections of regional climate, climate science clearly must be an important research focus of any climate service. Nevertheless, as the information produced by RCCs is aimed at assisting decision making in climate-sensitive sectors (e.g., agriculture, water resources, health), progress in climate knowledge must be matched by a commensurate understanding of how natural and social sciences can inform and support climate-resilient decisions and policy. Another critical need is the exploration of appropriate organizational and governance models for climate services institutions. A core challenge will be to combine the interests of the climate science community with the diverse needs of many relevant climate-sensitive sectors. For this reason the notion of a single institution (e.g., a “National Climate Service”) generating products and information seems insufficient or inappropriate, and alternative models must be explored.

Finally, as a concrete example of the translation of climate information into variables that are more relevant to sectoral stakeholders, we developed a pilot tool - called ProRindes - to anticipate the likely range of yields for important crops (maize, soybeans) in the Argentine Pampas throughout a cropping cycle (in this case, the 2015-2016 cropping season). The yield forecasts are based on computational models that simulate the growth and development of commercial crops. The forecasts were updated approximately every 10 days during the 2015-2016 cropping cycle. Updates were announced through Facebook and Twitter accounts and could be viewed at http://www.prorindes.com. At the time of writing, the Twitter account had about 975 followers, and received very favorable comments from the agricultural community in Argentina. This tool, therefore was successful in “translating” diagnostic climate information (weather observed up to the time of forecast) and climatological information (historical series observed in previous years) into relevant agricultural information (likely distribution of expected soybean and maize yields).
